If you buy the game and then decide to moan about how unfun and boring and repetetive it is, it's your fault. What you see in the description and screenshots/clips is all true. No lies.

First off, I'd like to mention the plot of the game. Lack of it, anyway. You're that little purple-haired guy (who's really fast btw. Like, too fast IMO) with an axe, a whip and a bow. And you're looking for an adventure. Or treasure. Or a sandwich. Or actually I've no idea, there's no story at all - not in description, not in menu, not in the game itself. You're just dropped in some underground-dungeon-thingy, now go and get those sweet hi-scores. Not every game needs an engaging story, that's true, but at least some background on what's going on would be nice. Though if developer decides to not care about it all, that's fine - it's the gameplay that matters most here.

So, what am I supposed to do in the game?
Well, that's pretty simple. You spawn at the top of the level, you're supposed to get to the bottom, get through the door to the next level, rinse, repeat. In meantime there's gold to pick up, monsters to slay (or avoid, since they give no gold) and spikes to fall on. The player has three weapons at his disposal - axe with a miserable melee range, whip with a mediocre range (though you can't hit anything in melee) and a bow with a range that probably covers the whole screen. Someone in reviews said that all weapons deal the same damage, but I don't think it's true - a crate needs two bow hits to be destroyed, but axe needs just two.

Gets boring/repetetive/monotonous quickly, no permanent unlocks/upgrades/achievs/anything.
There are no ways to spend gold, no achievements, no upgrades, nothing. Once you die, you don't even get to see your score - you're just booted back to the main menu. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I reviewed an earlier, broken version of the game. Take this review with a grain of salt as problems can get fixed. After my initial experience, I'm in no rush to play it again or rewrite a review.

Endorlight is a 2D retro-style rogue like platformer with broken controls that make the game literally unplayable. While the game is still in what it calls its alpha stage, its still a released product for money and a game this broken is a giant issue even if it can be fixed at a later time. An early release with this many problems can kill a game to the point that the developer might as well scrap this and start a new game.

To cover the game quick, you're put into a giant side-scrolling map that you need to platform and fight your way to the exit door. Each map is different and generated for you. Its a formula that's been done before and cloned before. In fact Endorlight uses a rogue-like platformer engine that does nothing to set itself apart from the out-of-the-box game engine.

The game has that retro-style old school charm with good chiptune music and a great art style. That's why this game is such a big disappointment. I want to play it, yet its unplayable in its current state.

So what's wrong with the controls? Every few seconds the game forgets your controls or nothing responds for another few seconds. Its as if the controls have just turned off. I can alt + tab out of the game and the keyboard still works. When I hop back into the game, the controls are non functional until it decides to let me play.

There are controls for jump, enter, shoot and melee, but it seems like shoot is the melee... only for a while though. Then the game changes its mind and lets the shoot be the shoot button again. Its baffling why this is such an issue and it hinders any sort of enjoyment out of the game.

On top of that there are rewindable keys, which is great, but each time you go to rebind them its forgotten what all my keys are. Oh and the cherry on the sundae is the fact that getting out of the menu requires you to restart the game. You'll get a new level generated for you and its just a frustration. Endorlight has two player support, but only keyboard controls for one player, and no keyboard or mouse support, so figure out how to control the second player.

When you do get control of your character, the jump is springy. Hold down the jump button and watch your character leap over and over again. These jumps are quick and the game plays a little too fast. You can scale a wall with your wall jumping ability, assuming the controls work. The melee attack can go through a wall and out the other side to hurt an enemy.

If you are hit, you are dead and death kicks you back to the menu. Since this game is in its alpha stage, there's just nothing here outside of a hand open willing to take your money. Do you believe in this game enough to give your money based on the great look, good sound and potential to have fun?

Endorlight has potential, but this cake needed more time in the oven rather than putting frosting on batter. Even with the game's cheap price, avoid the risk of buying it until the developer makes the right updates to even play the game.

Early Access Review

Another lackluster indie roguelike.  Is anyone really surprised?  To sum up what is obviously wrong with this game:
The platforming involves a lot of wall-jumping that seems out of place in a roguelike, and gives the game something of a badly implemented Meat Boy ripoff feel.Enemies all went to the goomba school of villainy.  They simply walk (or, rarely, hop) back and forth, typically staying on one platform, and damage you when they touch you.  This goes for bosses, too.  Also, they'll often explode in your face if you're not careful.  For that matter, chests and crates will also explode in your face.When the dev says 'bow', what they actually mean is 'magical rail gun'.  It has unlimited range, shoots in a perfectly straight line, fires rapidly, pierces any number of enemies, can be fired mid-jump, and never runs out of arrows.  Factor in the lack of enemy ranged attacks, and the frequent explosions, and there's rarely a good reason to use the other weapons.  To say it is overpowered is an understatement.   It makes combat easy and dull, and enemies are only ever a threat if you accidentally fall into a crowd of them.  Even 'bosses' will go down in a matter of seconds; just spam the rail gun.
Explosions destroy terrain, a power you yourself lack (as yet).  It's unlikely, but this has the potential to trap you and leave you unable to progress, which did come very close to happening to me.
Bear in mind, this is an early access game, and there are clear signs that it's a work in progress (e.g., you can collect gold from chests, but have no way of spending it), but even if the dev does fix the glaring issues and expand it a little, I can't see it ever becoming a good game.  Nothing about it shows promise - not the art, not the gameplay, and not even the planned features mentioned in the early access blurb.  Certainly not the story, which is completely nonexistent.  It's just yet another indie roguelike.

Update after reading other reviews:  Also, it's apparently just the demo game that comes with the engine it runs on, plus some minor cosmetic changes.  Is this even legal?  I mean, maybe - just, maybe - it'll grow into something more, but as it stands, it looks like the dev is basically charging for a reskin of someone else's lame game.

This is an early access review of the state of the game on 17.01.2016
Endorlight is a rogue-like dungeon explorer in the style of Spelunky (ish), but rather watered down. The game's point is to (at least for now) pass from one almost same level to another, while gathering gold and gems on your way lower and lower.

Concept As I've already said, the game is inspired by Spelunky (seems so). So gather monies, kill enemies, avoid traps and get to the end of the level. That said, at this moment, it's like Spelunky without some of the crucial features like: shops, bombs, ropes, bosses and pretty much - a point to all of this. You've got 3 weapons to use, but to be honest, axe and the whip feel almost the same (I think there might be slight a difference in the range?)

Gameplay The gameplay is pretty smooth and reactive, haven't noticed any glaring issues here. That said, there are a few minor annoyances. The gold and gems are unpickable for a while after falling out of a container, which made me go back to repick the items which I thought I had already picked. Another thing is the lack of possibility to break chests/pots/crates while standing on them, except by using a bow(?). There's also an issue with the whip that its range is actually shorter than the animation indicates. The last thing that really annoyed me, however, is not a bug is that the spikes will always instantly kill you when you fall on them, but there's a certain height, if you fall from they don't do anything to you. Sometimes the level design forces you to climb on a wall and jump on spikes and it's a guessing game if they will one-hit-ko you or will you actually manage to land safely.

Level DesignAs far as I noticed the levels are generated procedurally on each playthrough. Quite often you might find areas that are not accessible without being lucky with a bomb monster or a crate with a bomb. There is also a possibility that an unfortunate bomb will leave you trapped in an area and you'll be forced to restart.

GraphicsThe game looks pretty nice at first, if you like the oldschool pixelated graphics. After several levels it gets really dull though because you'll always visit levels in the same biome.

Music and SoundThere's only one song and, as far as I know, you can't turn it off. It gets repetitive quite quickly and you just stop paying attention to it or mute the sound altogether after a while. There's also a problem with sounds being played every time you press the attack button, instead of when you actually take a swing.

ContentAt this point, the game is really poor in terms of content. There are basically 4 types of enemies (+ a few reskins that just have more hp or slightly more damage on touch). You can gather gold, but there's no way to make any use out of it. There are 3 biomes, two of which share the exact same pool of monsters and neither happens to have anything that stands out from another (apart from the color). There's also no sense of progression - you can just jump down each level and proceed to another as there's not much point in killing anything or gathering gold anyway.

OverallThe game is at very early level of development and you should buy it only if you want to support the process of creation (hopefully). There's just no point in playing the game at the moment, as the amount of content will only keep you in it for half an hour or so (unless you're waiting for the cards to drop).

OVERVIEW
Endorlight

This game is in an alpha state at the time of this review, With that being said, it is still rather fun to play. It has many similarities to games like Spelunky or Steamworld Dig. It is a platfomer that utilizes procedural generation to construct the level and place enemies. You get 3 weapons to use which makes it rather fun: (1) axe for short range, (2) whip for medium range, (3) bow for long range. You decend each level to reach the exit while picking up treasure along the way. It offers local coop which works well with the wired xbox 360 controllers I have (I am not able to vouch for other brands). Just as a warning, there is friendly fire.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/428430/

PROS & CONS
Pros
Local coop

Boss fights
Cons
Both players in coop use the same sprite
The deadzone on the controller joystick needs to be adjusted by the devs to avoid ghosting the player

SUMMARY & FINAL RATING
This game is in alpha at the time of this review, but is still very playable. The local coop was fun and the friendly fire added a bit of nostalgia for games from the 80s and early 90s. If you like coop platformers like Spelunky or Steamworld Dig, this game is one to keep on your radar. For $3 USD you can support this developer in creating a great game.

7/10
